caption: Just passed this statue on the bus. Why is this military man standing on the shoulders of African woman? He served in the Franco-Prussian war, yet the French administration chose to honor him for being a colonist. And proudly at that. Wow.

He took an active part in the expansion and consolidation of the colonial empire , particularly in Africa. He founded a method that combined brutality, as with the repression of the Menalamba insurrection in Madagascar , with economic development after a gradual conquest of the territories
Can anyone tell me why African women carrying the Marshal Gallieni ?!!!
Big wonderful military  museum

Disgusting monument to colonization. Why has no one pulled this down yet?

Les invalides is a place and historical monument that I love in Paris not far from the Effeil tower on the other side the Alexandre bridge |||
Symbol of French colonial brutalization. Does not deserve to be glorified in the public space without even mentioning his crimes.
Where Napoleon sleeps. It's good for a quick look around, but it's quite difficult to move around after viewing.
Excellent place to relax and an afternoon at the museum
This symbol of French imperialism must be destroyed. There is no pride in colonialism.

Marshal Gallieni is a historical figure of French colonialism. He is known in particular for his terribly racist and misogynistic ideals (4 women from different cultures who carry him on this statue). The presence of this symbol in public space is unacceptable in my opinion. This is not a choice of the population and living in an environment accepting ideals such as those represented by this statue only increases hostility and maintains racial and misogynistic problems. Removing this symbol from public space does not mean that we erase historical memory, but we remove what this statue symbolizes.
Every Sunday morning youngtimer meeting this sunny morning it was great

A beautiful historical monument. The place where the monument is located carries away into history. Which everyone needs to know. Let the memory of wars that should not be repeated be preserved for a long time.

Statue of Marshal Gallieni located south of the Hôtel des Invalides, who spent a large part of his career in Africa. In 1914, he was governor of Paris and directed operations on the Marne to stop the advance of the German armies, then he was minister of war in 1915 and 16. Opposite is the statue of Marshal Fayolle who participated in military operations in the Somme in 1916 and in Italy in 1917, he commanded an army group in 1918 which participated in the last military operations before the armistice.

Monument located near the Invalides....it is a sober bronze statue of a French major general... The monument was erected on Place Vauban in 1926 (author - sculptor Jean Boucher). The square in front of the House of the Disabled, the tomb of the great warriors of France.
Probably goes unnoticed by many
Beautiful monument near Invalides Cathedral. But you don't have to come here specifically for that reason. It's actually not worth it because there's nothing else to see here.
This statue has no place in the heart of Paris. Gallieni's colonial past cannot be put aside, this statue should be taken down.
